review.title: Local Search for Minimum Weight Dominating Set with Two-Level Configuration Checking and Frequency Based Scoring Function
review.abstract: The Minimum Weight Dominating Set (MWDS) problem is an important generalization of the Minimum Dominating Set (MDS) problem with extensive applications. This paper proposes a new local search algorithm for the MWDS problem, which is based on two new ideas. The first idea is a heuristic called two-level configuration checking (CC2), which is a new variant of a recent powerful configuration checking strategy (CC) for effectively avoiding the recent search paths. The second idea is a novel scoring function based on the frequency of being uncovered of vertices. Our algorithm is called CC2FS, according to the names of the two ideas. The experimental results show that, CC2FS performs much better than some state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of solution quality on a broad range of MWDS benchmarks.

sections.text: This paper proposes a new local search algorithm for the MWDS problem, based on two new ideas: the first idea is a heuristic, so-called two-step configuration check (CC2), which is a new variant of a current powerful configuration check strategy (CC) to effectively avoid the current search paths; the second idea is a novel scoring function based on the frequency of detection of nodes; our algorithm is called CC2FS, according to the names of the two ideas; and the experimental results show that CC2FS performs much better on a wide range of MWDS benchmarks in terms of solution quality than some state-of-the-art algorithms.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Considering an undirected graph G, a dominant group D is a subset of wells such that each vertex is not in D to at least one member of D. The Minimum Dominating Set (MDS) problem is to identify the smallest approximation problem within a diagram showing the total weight of wells in it.The MWDS problem has played a prominent role in various real-world domains, such as social networks, communications networks and industrial applications. For example, Houmaidi et al. are making the first known attempt to solve the sparse wavelength problem, where the MWDS problem is used to reduce the number of full wavelength converters in the wavelength division.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: An undirected graph G = (V, E) includes a node set V = {v1, v2,..., vn} of n nodes along with a set E = {e1, e2,..., em} of m edges, where each edge e = {v, u} connects two nodes u and v, and these two nodes are called edge endpoints. The distance between two nodes u and v, denoted by dist (u, v), is the number of edges in a shortest path from u to v, and dist (u, u) = 0 in particular. For a node v, we define its ith-plane neighborhood as Ni (v) = {u | dist (u, v) = i}, and we denote Nk (v) = k (v) = 1Ni (v). The first level neighborhood N1 (v) is commonly referred to as N (v), and we denote a problem Ni [v] = Ni (v) as a problem that includes v (v).

sections.heading: 2.1 Local Search for MWDS
sections.text: Local search algorithms perform the search on the corresponding search space of the problem; the search space is implicitly defined by the way the algorithm transforms one candidate solution into another. In the MWDS problem, local search algorithms usually maintain a candidate solution S V during the search. A vertex v is covered by S when v N [S], and is otherwise uncovered. Also, the state of a vertex v is denoted by sv {1, 0}, so that sv = 1 means that a vertex v is covered by a candidate solution S, and sv = 0 means that it is uncovered. For a vertex, its age is defined as the number of steps it has taken since the last time it changed its state (added or removed w.r.t. the retained candidate solution S), and when we say that the oldest vertex is covered by a candidate solution S, and sv = it is revealed.

sections.heading: 4. A Novel Scoring Function for MWDS
sections.text: Local search algorithms decide which vertex is selected according to their score. Therefore, the scoring function for vertex plays a crucial role in the algorithm, which has a direct impact on the intensification and diversification of the search.

sections.heading: 4.1 The Previous Scoring Function for MWDS
sections.text: Recently, four scoring functions were presented to solve MWDS (Potluri & Singh, 2013).We list the definitions of these score1 (u) = d (u) w (u) score2 (u) = W (u) w (u) score3 (u) = W (u) − w (u) score4 (u) = d (u) × W (u) w (u) score2 (u) where u / S, d (u) actually the number of uncovered (non-dominated) neighbors of a given vertex uand W (u) is the sum of the weights of the uncovered neighbors of u. The results of this experiment (Potluri & Singh, 2013) show that the first, second, and last heuristic functions lead to similar performance, without a clear pattern of a particular greedy vertex uand W (u) is the sum of the weights of the uncovered neighbors of u

sections.heading: 4.2 The Frequency based Scoring Function
sections.text: In this thesis, we introduce a novel scoring function, taking into account the frequency of vertices, which can be regarded as a type of dynamic information indicating the cumulative effectiveness of the vertex search. Intuitively, when a vertex is normally revealed, we should encourage the algorithm to select a vertex to make it covered. Specifically, each vertex has an additional property, frequency, which is indicated by Freq [v]. The frequency of each vertex is initialized to 1. After each iteration of the local search, the frequency value of each vertex uncovered is increased by one. During the search process, we apply the frequency of the vertex to decide which vertex to add or remove. Based on this consideration, we propose a new score function, which is formally defined as a folding point. sections.heading: 7. Empirical Results
sections.text: We compare CC2FS with five competitors across a wide range of benchmarks in terms of quality of solutions and runtime. Runtime is measured in seconds. First, we present the test instances, five competitors and the experimental procedures of our experiments. There are eight benchmarks selected in our experiment, including T1, UDG, two weighted versions of DIMACS, two weighted versions of BHOSLIB, and many real graphics. We present the benchmarks in the following areas: T1 Benchmarks, UDG, two versions of DIMACS, two versions of BHOSLIB, two versions of BHOSLIB, two benchmarks.

sections.text: Table 3 shows the comparison results to the UDG benchmark. In these cases, the solution value obtained by EA / G-IR and ACO-PP-LS is almost equivalent to CC2FS, the expert for one instance V1000U150. But the real runtime of all instances solved by CC2FS is always less than 0.2 seconds, and CC2FS solves faster than EA / G-IR and ACO-PP-LS. sections.heading: 7.3 Results on BHOSLIB Benchmarks
sections.text: In Tables 4 and 5, CC2FS is compared with ACO-PP-LS using the two weighted BHOSLIB benchmarks, with one assuming the weighting function w (vi) = (i mod 200) + 1 (Table 4), while the other assuming the weighting function w (vi) = 1 (Table 5). We compare the number of optimal solutions found by the two algorithms. CC2FS once again dramatically outperforms its competitors ACO-PP-LS. Any cases of this benchmark could be solved faster by our algorithm than ACO-PP-LS. More importantly, our algorithm could find better solution values.

sections.heading: 7.4 Results on DIMACS Benchmarks
sections.text: The experimental results of the two weighted DIMACS benchmarks are shown in Tables 6 and 7. It is encouraging to see that the performance of CC2FS remains surprisingly good in these cases, where ACO-PP-LS performs very poorly. Despite the performance advantage of CC2FS, there are some exceptions in the weighting function of w (vi) = (i mod 200) + 1, such as gen200 _ p0.9 _ 44 and C500.9. For the weighting function w (vi) = 1, our algorithms in Table 7 show a significant improvement in real-time and the best solution value than ACO-PP-LS. Given the good performance of CC2FS on the DIMACS benchmark with major benchmarks, we are confident that it may be able to resolve larger graph instances.

sections.text: The results in Table 8 and Table 9 show that there are 58 diagrams for which ACO-PP-LS does not provide a dominant quantity, indicating the effectiveness of our algorithm. In the remaining instances (16), CC2FS finds better dominant quantities than ACO-PP-LS. In addition, CC2FS may find the good dominant quantities of all given massive diagrams (74).

sections.heading: 8. Summary and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, a local search algorithm called CC2FS was introduced to solve the problem of minimum weight dominating set (MWDS). We proposed a new configuration verification strategy, namely CC2based on the two-tiered neighborhood of vertices, in order to remember the relevant information of remote and added vertices and avoid visiting the most recent paths. In addition, we introduced a new frequency-based scoring feature to solve MWDS. Experimental results showed that CC2FS performs significantly better than state-of-the-art algorithms in almost all cases in terms of solution quality and runtime. In terms of future work, we are considering further improving the CC2FS algorithm by integrating some other ideas such as strong configuration testing (Wang et al., 2016). Also, we would like to test our algorithms on other instances, including larger diagrams. Among the planned research guidelines on the proposed search strategies are some other important application of the new search algorithms to local scalgorithms, and some of the other algorithms on the new algorithms proposed.

referenceMentions.context: In the work of Nitash and Singh (2014), a swarm intelligence algorithm called ABC uses an artificial bee colony method to solve MWDS.

In the work of Bouamama and Blum (2016), a randomized population-based iterated greedy approach R-PBIG is proposed to tackle MWDS, which maintains a population of solutions and applies the basic steps of an iterated greedy algorithm to each member of the population.

The CC strategy has been successfully applied to a number of well-known combinatorial optimization problems, including Vertex Cover (Cai et al., 2011; Cai, Su, Luo, & Sattar, 2013; Fang, Chu, Qiao, Feng, & Xu, 2014; Li, Hu, Zhang, & Yin, 2016), Set Covering (Wang, Ouyang, Zhang, & Yin, 2015; Wang, Yin, Ouyang, & Zhang, 2016), Clique problem (Wang, Cai, & Yin, 2016),

Recently, an interesting strategy called Configuration Checking (CC) (Cai et al., 2011) was proposed to handle the cycling problem in local search.
Thus, we can easily devise a CC strategy for the MWDS problem, following the one for the vertex cover problem (Cai et al., 2011).
The weight of vertices being covered in score2 is taken into account (Jovanovic et al., 2010).
